newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crude firmer, little solace for Minas.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude firmer, little solace for Minas.

text.p: Asian crude prices were firmer on Wednesday with little movement seen in premium levels for regional or MidEast grades.
Traders said trading of MidEast crude for April was coming to an end, although there were a handful of cargoes available.
Light sweet regional grades were generally tight and were already being traded for April liftings. A producer sold 450,000 barrels of April Miri crude at OSP plus around five cents, traders said.
But heavy sweet grades remained under the cosh with Minas supplies still seen as ample.

Traders reported that Pertamina was making efforts to push crude into storage to keep the market balanced because of the maintenance shut down of the 120,000-bpd Dumai refinery and the shut down of the 125,000-bpd Balangon CDU.
Some traders estimated that as much as one million barrels of Minas could still be available to the market and Pertamina might soon seek to make an official additional allocation.
Minas was still assessed at ICP less 50/60 cents after China paid those levels earlier this week for about 900,000 barrels.
But Duri was being talked at ICP less 20 to 30 cents after support from blenders and arbitrage talk.
One trader has acquired various lots of Duri for blending at levels from ICP less 50 to 20 cents and another trader was heard buying Duri on a fixed-rate and floating-rate basis.
Tapis premiums were being talked lower, but the crude was considered difficult to value in premium terms over quoted prices, reflected in recent deals being done against the OSP.
Traders broadly assessed the differential at 75 cents to $1.00.
